projectDesc.p: "The greedy man who tasted urine" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Curialis unus e nostris notae avaritiae, saepe mensam familiae accedebat, dum comederet, degustans vinum, an satis aquatum esset:
app.rdg: A colleague of ours in the curia, known for his greed, would often come to the servants’ table while taking his dinner to taste the wine to see if it was watered enough.

app.lem: simulabat autem se id agere, ut bono vino uterentur.
app.rdg: However, he only pretended to do this so that they would use the good wine.

app.lem: Hoc cum animadvertissent nonnulli, tandem communicato consilio recentem quandoque urinam pro vino in mensa supposuere, qua hora venturum hominem suspicabantur.
app.rdg: When some servants noticed this, they made a plan and at the hour they suspected the man would attend, they placed fresh urine on the table instead of wine.

app.lem: Accessit ille more suo, et cum urinam bibisset, nauseans ac semieructans, magno clamore abscessit, minatus multa illis qui haec conati essent.
app.rdg: He arrived in his usual way and when he had drunk the urine, he got nauseous and almost threw up, he left the place with loud shouts and made great threats against the ones who had planned this.
The servants then finished their meal with laughter.

app.lem: Hoc eius rei machinator mihi postmodum retulit multo cum risu.
app.rdg: All of this was told to me later with much laughter by the perpetrator of the act.
